none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. D. Lee, February 15, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. D. Lee, February 15, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 13 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Letter from S. D. Lee, President of the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Mississippi, to Professor Louis L. McInnis expressing support for McInnis's institution and reporting that Lee has sent copies of a Legislative Committee Report to George Pfeuffer in Austin at McInnis's request. Lee expresses hope that McInnis's legislature will provide adequate appropriations and conveys that the Mississippi college models itself after Michigan College of Agriculture with perceived improvements.

body.value:
[Header]
Agricultural and Mechanical College,
OF MISSISSIPPI.
[/Header]

[Boxed Text Left]
Executive Department,
S. D. LEE, PRESIDENT.
[/Boxed Text Left]

Agricultural College, Feb'y 15' 1883

Prof L. L. McInnis
My dear Sir
At your request, I sent to
Honble Geo. Pfeuffer at Austin, a 1/2 dozen
copies of Report of Legislative Committee &
wrote him to that effect - I do hope your
Legislature will give you ample appro-
-priations and that you may eminently
succeed as an industrial College - We
feel here that we are on the right road,
- We modeled after the Michigan College
and think we are an improvement
With best wishes,

Yours truly
S. D. Lee

**Here's how I approached this transcription task:**

As a seasoned transcriptionist, my initial step was to meticulously analyze the request, ensuring I fully understood the role, task, guidelines, and expected output. My goal was clear: to accurately transcribe the handwritten text from the image, preserving the original layout and addressing any uncertainties with appropriate markings.

Next, I delved into the image itself, identifying its type, the official letterhead of the "Agricultural and Mechanical College OF MISSISSIPPI," the date line, the recipient (Prof. L.L. McInnis), the salutation, and the signature of S.D. Lee. I took note of the purple ink and cursive handwriting, which I recognized as potentially belonging to Stephen Dill Lee.

Following this, I began a methodical, step-by-step transcription, starting with the header, then the date line (paying close attention to the abbreviated "Feb'y" and handwritten year), the recipient, the salutation, the body paragraphs, and finally, the signature. For each element, I carefully deciphered the handwriting, including the fraction (1/2), and phrases like "Honble" (for Honorable),  and recognized "Pfeuffer" as the likely last name, then reviewed context.

A critical aspect of my process was constant self-correction and refinement. I scrutinized each line, paying attention to even the smallest details, such as punctuation, line breaks, and potential misspellings. Any uncertainties were flagged, and context was utilized to arrive at the most accurate transcription. I also double-checked the "Legislature" and other words, and the "eminently" spelling, and the "road" punctuation.

I considered the visual layout and structure, placing the "Executive Department" box as it visually appeared in the letter. I also made sure that the line breaks were kept, and the handwritten parts like the "Feb'y" date, the "1/2", and words like "eminently" was carefully rendered. I kept the "Honble" form of writing in text format.

I then conducted a final review against the image, ensuring that every detail, every character, and every mark was accurately represented. I also ensured that phrases like "eminent" was correctly captured despite a slight blurriness in the script. The entire process was one of constant refinement, ensuring a faithful and accurate transcription of the original document, which will be the output.
